poll_list.title: Oh no, this should not be here - July 8, 2022

discourse_list.title: Fire drill, request for discussion + informal polls

content.content: Background Immunefi Security has a core unit mandate to perform a fire drill. However, our fire drill was delayed because it turned out that nobody knew exactly what we were suppose to do. DeFi Safety offers services under the fire drill category focused on checking a multisig. However, it was not clear how to apply a similar kind of approach to Maker’s governance system.  With the introduction of Recognized Delegates, executive spells are often passed in less than 24 hours and usually within a few days (see Feb & Jan). This seems like a quick reaction; however, these are regularly scheduled executive spells. How long would it take to pass an unexpected, unannounced emergency executive spell?  Proposal  A fire drill will be declared every month at a random day and time.   Delegates will be asked via emergency communication channels to sign a message.   Reaction time will be measured and recorded.     Benefits  Although there is currently a track record of Recognized Delegates passing executives promptly, there is no direct incentive for them to do so. According to @prose11, the current rule is that an executive has to be supported (or opposed ) within one week to fulfill the Executive Participation metric. Conducting a periodic fire drill will provide assurance that Recognized Delegates can react promptly to an emergency.   A plot of reaction times shall be displayed on a Delegate’s information page. This will help MKR holders to decide where best to delegate their MKR.   Median (or some other quantile) reaction time could be incorporated into the Recognized Delegate compensation performance modifier.     Discussion Points Is monthly a good frequency? Fire drills are annoying, but we must stay vigilant. It’s a necessary evil.      Every two months Monthly Every two weeks (fortnightly) Abstain     0 voters     How fast is fast enough for a Delegate to react?      12 hours 24 hours 36 hours 48 hours Abstain     0 voters     Should we incorporate some measure of reaction time into the Recognized Delegate compensation performance modifier?     Yes No Abstain     0 voters     According to TechOps (@Jeannette_Rigor), Signal (primary) and WhatsApp (backup) are used for emergency communications to Recognized Delegates. Both of these services rely on a central server. Are any decentralized solutions up to the task yet? EPNS? I would like to thank @prose11, @monkey.irish, and @Derek for contributing to this idea. Cc: @TravinImmunefi

This week’s unplanned executive was a good example of passing a spell within hours of it being posted (actually it might have been a record?) I’m not sure what alerting mechanism you had in mind, but discord/forum contact points are probably insufficient, so pager duty or other might be required in which case you’ll need an SLA-type flowchart of who to call in which situations and what the expectations are for participation.

Really - really appreciate this signal coming up @psychonaut so thank you for the post. One other point in these emergency drills (not just for delegates but governance as well). We desperately need to do a EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN fire drill and need to determine how to conduct this. Point here is that I don’t believe delegates can activate the ES directly, but only MKR IOU holders or MKR holders could.  Also the threshold at 100K is higher than current delegated total.  F Formally simulating whether MKR could exit MKR from governance and dropped into the ES in a timely manner is much more difficult to assess vs. whether they can just sign a (I am here ready to act) tx. As added color:  I voted YES to the response performance being part of delegate performance here, but I think some real discussion about what is ‘appropriate’ response to qualify or modify compensation would be warranted.

psychonaut:  How long would it take to pass an unexpected, unannounced emergency executive spell?   Judging by yesterday, less than 5 minutes. Admittedly there was like ~36 hours notice. But that is less than the time we’d have to react in the event of a governance attack. So in general, this was a good sign.     psychonaut:  A fire drill will be declared every month at a random day and time.   Monthly feels more frequent than necessary.     psychonaut:  A plot of reaction times shall be displayed on a Delegate’s information page. This will help MKR holders to decide where best to delegate their MKR.   Once we have some data, we may ask DUX to surface it in some fashion on the voting portal. I’m not sure exactly what this will look like, though.     psychonaut:  How fast is fast enough for a Delegate to react?   This is essentially defined by the GSM setting. We should use the data from fire drills as an input into  determining safe values for the GSM, rather than the other way around.

I voted Abstain except for voting 48 hours for “How fast is fast enough for a Delegate to react?” Realistically, there might be delegates who might be traveling or have their own emergencies. So anything at or above 24 hours seem more appropriate. Like 12 hour would mean that if the notice happens when one is sleeping then he/she has to respond within such a short time after waking up. This seems not so feasible.

ACREinvest:  For the record here, Let it be known I gave a personal mobile phone number having been warned there might be a need to vote. I was never contacted about the vote and told later that they already had what was needed to pass the Executive.   Hey there, thanks for bringing this up! We’re working on a retrospective, but no reason to wait on addressing this point. This drill was designed to be as low impact as possible, with a ping on the Maker Discord and Forum for Recognized delegates. In a true emergency situation we would be knocking on every comms channel we have available. However in this one, the goal was just to see how effective voters would be responding to an unknown event at a poor time. With nearly 90,000 MKR voting on the poll with no additional vote wrangling I was personally quite pleased. We were able to get an onchain response from many, and a few more indicated they would have been able to go vote in an actual emergency situation. My goal was to balance a stress test with respecting people’s time over the weekend and felt this structure would allow us a genuine test without proving inconvenient for the community. We’ll be gathering more feedback to see how we can do this better in the future, if we feel the need for a surprise drill again.
